Abstract: This study explores the neural mechanisms underlying visual representations through advanced decoding techniques and multivariate pattern analysis. By examining object representations and their associated neural dynamics, we gain insights into the complex processes of visual perception and cognition. Our research employs state-of-the-art neuroimaging methods to investigate the representational structure of visual information in the brain. We demonstrate how internal representations are formed and manipulated across different brain regions and time scales. The findings reveal intricate patterns of neural activity that correspond to specific object categories and features. Furthermore, we uncover the temporal evolution of these representations, shedding light on the dynamic nature of visual processing. This work contributes to our understanding of how the brain encodes and decodes visual information, with implications for fields such as computer vision, artificial intelligence, and cognitive neuroscience. Our results provide a foundation for future studies exploring the neural basis of visual perception and object recognition.
